arm_group.description: Ingest 500ml of placebo prior to metabolic measures.

brief_summary.textblock:
This study will investigate the effects of hydrothermally modified starch (SuperStarch) in
      adults. SuperStarch, originally developed as a drink for children with glycogen storage
      disease, is a slow digestible carbohydrate, maintaining blood sugar levels over extended
      periods. Therefore, it could be beneficial to exercise and mental performance, and could
      possibly have fat loss effects by increasing feelings of fullness. In this study, measures
      will be taken in 25 men to assess mental function, appetite, and metabolism to determine the
      processes involved in possible fat loss.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of a Carbohydrate Drink on Cognitive Function and Exercise Performance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  healthy, 18 to 35 year old man or woman.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  smoker

          -  pregnancy

          -  taking part in other research.

          -  followed a weight loss diet in the previous 6 months.

          -  history of gastrointestinal, endocrine, cardiovascular disease or diabetes.

          -  neurological or psychiatric condition that may cause cognitive dysfunction.

intervention.description: Ingest 500ml of placebo prior to metabolic measures.

facility.name: Exercise Nutrition Research Laboratory, Western University

clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of a Carbohydrate Drink on Cognitive Function and Exercise Performance

primary_outcome.time_frame: Four 10 minute measures throughout 90 min protocol (1 day).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Four appetite ratings throughout 90 min protocol (1 day).
2 computerized tests (Stroop Test, Trail Making test)  repeated 3 times throughout 90 min protocol (1 day).

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Treatment
